examples.name: Project Management Tool
examples.description: Full JTBD analysis for distributed team project management
highlights: Forces analysis showing meeting fatigue as key push force
Job stories focused on async coordination
Solution mapping prioritizing features by job importance

examples.name: Meal Kit Service
examples.description: JTBD analysis for meal kit delivery service
highlights: Three dimensions: functional, emotional, and social jobs
Decision fatigue as major push force
Anxiety about cooking skills as barrier to switching

examples.name: CRM for Small Business
highlights: Switching triggers: specific moments that force change
Anxiety about micromanagement as adoption barrier
Habit force: spreadsheet familiarity is powerful

examples.name: Fitness App
examples.description: Job discovery for fitness tracking app
examples.useCase: Mobile consumer app in crowded market
highlights: Discovery phase identifying invisible progress as core struggle
Job clustering reveals three main themes
Switching triggers reveal why users abandon fitness apps

fullWorkflow.description: Complete JTBD analysis from discovery to solution mapping

discoveryOnly.description: Focus on identifying customer jobs without solution mapping

beginner.reason: Simplest example showing job discovery fundamentals
keyLearnings: How to identify jobs vs features

intermediate.reason: Introduces three job dimensions and forces analysis
keyLearnings: Forces diagram: push, pull, anxiety, habits
How job stories capture context and causality

advanced.reason: Complete workflow with solution mapping and prioritization

b2b.notes: B2B jobs often focus on efficiency, coordination, and business outcomes. Emotional dimension relates to professional competence.

consumer.notes: Consumer jobs often have strong emotional and social dimensions. Habit forces are typically stronger.

habitForces: Simplicity of current (even if inadequate) solution
